okay let us start now
do all of you have a terminal to begin with?
it would be nice to explore the commands on the go. Please make sure you have this for future sessions atleast
most of what I cover today, is what you already know
okay, can anyone tell me what ls does?
what is the full form?
list is the full form of ls
oh my bad. Yes ls lists all the files in the present directory
there are tons of other options that can be used along with ls
for instance:
<@UAGTJ7M8X> can you tell me what ls -l does?
how is it different from the barebones ls?
It gives a long formate like it include last time used etc
yeah. more precisely, it mentions the size, permissions, modified date and time, owner of the file, etc.
To see the filesize in human readable format, we can use ls -lh command
<@UAGR7CFEJ> what does ls -a do?
sorry but what is barebones?
-h flag stands for human readable
without any flag, only the ls command
<@UAG0A3ZNH> has joined the channel
Reveals hidden filea
Files*
Is it?
<@UAGR3HCLW> can you tell me what ls -R does? Do this in a directory with subdirectories :stuck_out_tongue:
Even LS -a mentions current and prarent directory's
lists recursively directory tree
Also
yeah. Folders might contain many hidden files (usually beginning with a dot in their names, like .bashrc, .vimrc, .profile) etc.
yeah, correct
A better way to visualize the directory structure is by using tree command. But you will have to install the program in the first place
okay, let's move onto the cd command
cd as you know, is used to change the working directory
you all must check out zsh terminal
there's a nice plugin called oh-my-zsh also
it's really cool
<@UAFPA8G59> has joined the channel
now, can everyone pitch in the different ways we can use cd command?
like moving to parent folder, ... etc?
<@UAFL06YEM> has joined the channel
cd~username does that i guess
It is important that ls is in lowercase as LS isn't a command
cd .. moves up one directory
moving to the home directory can be done using "cd ~ "
but moving one directory above needs : cd ..
yeah
how do you move up two directories at a time?
yeah, correct

As an aside, in the zsh terminal with that plugin, you can directly start typing in the folder name, it will have cached all of the previous working directories. It's a great productivity boost for devs.
is everyone with me so far?
any doubts?
is zsh a separate program
you can tell me if I am fast, slow, boring, whatever
it's another terminal itself, like bash
so we have to install zsh right
<https://gist.github.com/derhuerst/12a1558a4b408b3b2b6e>
Do all terminals need Linux OS?
terminal is a program on the linux distributions, which can be used to create, manage and work with other processes
now, you have terminals on windows also, apart from mac OSX
okay, moving on. Can anyone tell me what's the different between relative and absolute address?
relative address is dealing with memory locations with respect to another one
you can use bash on windows also, but you don't have the freedom to tinker with stuff, like you do in linux
Relative addresses can be diff
windows abstracts away a lot of the details from the user
But absolute address is same no matter which directory u working in
like if you have a pointer p pointing to a int and p++ will point to the address + 4bytes
correct, absolute addresses are specified from the root directory
the relative addresses are specified wrt the current directory
I am not sure if the pointers analogy is the best way to describe the situation. Especially, when we have soft links and all
you guys can check out what "cd - " does
it's used to move directly to the last used directory
okay, shall we move on to pwd command?
S
can we use pointers to  access and manipulate these addresses?
<@UAFHUCYAG> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAFHUCYAG/FAGJCLE13/code_for_pwd.sh|code for pwd>

file.name: code_for_pwd.sh
file.title: code for pwd
file.preview:
cd ~
ln -s /var/www/html/ htm
cd htm
/bin/pwd -L
file.preview_highlight:
cd ~
ln -s /var/www/html/ htm
cd htm
/bin/pwd -L

text: can we type cd ../../ n times to move up n directories?
I am not sure I got your question, but yeah that's how it's implemented in the file system
the commands to create a file, create soft and hard links, delete a file - all involving storing the addresses of blocks of memory(which together make up a file)
storing and playing with the addresses of the blocks
but these are not exposed to the user per se, that's why we need an abstraction called a file system

text: What is soft link
I took the pain of creating sym links or soft links to show the difference between -P and -L flags for the pwd command

<@UAF4ZQ7BJ> think of a terminal as just another program allowing you to do a bunch of stuff. Back in the day, there was no GUI. No mouse even at one point. So everything was done by issuing a specific set of commands to your computer. Everything from file handling to system management. And all of that was done through an interface called the Command Line Interface(CLI) which we now call the terminal. You can do everything you can do using a GUI on a terminal.

And no. You don't need a Linux OS for a terminal. Every major OS has a terminal, though the instructions you issue and what you can do has its limitations.
soft links will be covered in detail in the future sessions. But what can be understood is - two different files can be linked together keeping a single copy of the data on the hard disk
For e.g on the windows command line you have `dir` command to list directories and files whereas Linux bash terminals use `ls`
something like a pointer?
yeah, it's actually a pointer
so pwd -L flag will only show the output, without minding the soft links
but you will get a different output if you use a -P flag for the pwd command
thanks a lot
also, I have used /bin/pwd command in the above snippet because, pwd refers to the shell's implementation of the command
but /bin/pwd refers to the specific binary file, which is already present in the system

<@UAFPA8G59> If there are n directories to move up to, then yes.

If you type `ls - a` in any directory it will list all the files and directories including the hidden ones. You will find two files `. ` and `.. `. Here the first one refers to the current directory and the second one to the parent directory.
so when you are writing an application, if you don't want your applucation to break, when the bash implementation of pwd is modified, you will want to use binary implementations
So you can keep doing `../../..` n number of times because every directory has a `.. ` that points to the parent directory.
it's fine if you don't get the soft link part completely, just remember that we have flags to get the resolved path names also

kinda

<@UAFHUCYAG> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAFHUCYAG/FAGJNP5K7/cat_command_usage.sh|cat command usage>

file.name: cat_command_usage.sh
file.title: cat command usage
file.preview:
cat <filename>, cat -n <filename> # displays line numbers also
cat file1 file2
cat >inp_file # enter your input and finally hit Ctrl+D
cat file1; cat file2; cat file3; # working with multiple files
file.preview_highlight:
cat <filename>, cat -n <filename> # displays line numbers also
cat file1 file2
cat >inp_file # enter your input and finally hit Ctrl+D
cat file1; cat file2; cat file3; # working with multiple files
​

text: I want you guys to try out all these commands
the -n flag is used to include line numbers when it displays the contents of the files - improves readability
<@UAGTJ7M8X> Remember creating a shortcut in windows? Think of it as a something pretty much like that. More details will be given in future sessions.
the sixth line shows, how all the output of the cat command can be plummeled into another file. this is very useful
<@UAFPA8G59> what's the doubt?
for the command shown in the 4th line: we can take input from STDIN (keyboard) until the user hits Ctrl+D. All of that text will be saved into the specified file
anything that you didn't understand here?
cat is actually used to concatenate files. It concatenates them and prints an o/p
What he's trying to say is, if you application uses the pwd command, if the version that bash uses is modified then your application might break. So we specifically tell it use the binary at /bin/pwd

text: <@UAH07G9T9> commented on <@UAFHUCYAG>’s file <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAFHUCYAG/FAGJNP5K7/cat_command_usage.sh|cat command usage>: A semicolon is used as a separator between commands. In this case the output of the two will be the same. But having `cat file1 file2` will give you the concatenation of the two files and you can do whatever you want with it(append it to another file etc)

cat file1; cat file2; cat file3; # working with multiple files

comment.comment: A semicolon is used as a separator between commands. In this case the output of the two will be the same. But having `cat file1 file2` will give you the concatenation of the two files and you can do whatever you want with it(append it to another file etc)

text: is third command changes any of file original contents

Are you sure? Wouldn't that just print the contents of file1 and then file2?
Read the question again
it overwrites them
means
deletes the current content and adds the new one
whatever was wriiten in the file at first will be replaced with whatever u just typed
ohh

So
`cat file1>file2` will overwrite file2 with contents of file1

`cat file1>>file2` will append contents of file2 at the end of file1.


This is best seen when you type them out in a terminal yourself. So at the end of this I want all of you to run all of these on your terminals and to confirm the functionalities. You can raise doubts if something doesn't look right.
works
oh yeah

root.text: Let's say you have a file file1.txt with some text in it. There's another file file2.txt. How would you append the contents of file1.txt at the end of file2.txt?

text: Question unanswered.

attachments.fallback: [May 1st, 2018 9:32 AM] kaushikskalmady: Let's say you have a file file1.txt with some text in it. There's another file file2.txt. How would you append the contents of file.txt at the end of file2.txt?
attachments.text: Let's say you have a file file1.txt with some text in it. There's another file file2.txt. How would you append the contents of file.txt at the end of file2.txt?

text: so, do you want me to continue?
cat file2>>file
or shall we call it a day?
cat file1.txt file2.txt >>file2.txt
What would that do? Can you go through it one by one by breaking it down?
Sure? :p
pretty sure
I want to add thing to the end of file2, so should file2 be on the left of the >> or the right?
left

Also, when you see something like `command file1 > file2`

contents of file1 will be used by the command and the output will be written to file2 by overwriting the current contents of file2. Cool?
its actually cat file1.txt >>file2.txt
s
oh that's a good way to remember
cat file1>>file2 appends file1 to file2 right?

The answer is `cat file1.txt>>file2.txt`

Breaking it down

`cat file1.txt` display content so file1.txt.
`cat file1.txt >>file2.txt` display contents of file1.txt and redirect it to the end of file2.txt (append)
<@UAGR3HCLW> you are right.
oh its the reverse
`>` is known as the redirection. If you notice cat only displays the output. The reason it gets added to file2 is because you `redirect` the output there?

So if you break down the command `cat file1 > file2`

It's actually made of two parts.

First part `cat file1` displays contents of file1

Second part `> file2` redirect output of the command that preceded the `>` to file2
So you can actually do `ls>file2`
What do you think that will do?
write the output given by ls to file
yeah same
Perfect. So next time you see a `>`you should realize it just means take the output from what preceeded `>` and redirect it to the file specified after `>`

# -p --parent: creates the parent folders automatically

text: <@UAFHUCYAG> uploaded a file: <https://ieeeunixsmp.slack.com/files/UAFHUCYAG/FAHC34Q8N/rmdir_options.png|flags for rm dir>
Also, you can always do `command --help` and the terminal will display info about that command.
Try with `ls --help` and `cat - - help`
use the `man command_name` to get the manual pages
Guys you can ping any of us if you have any doubts, you could post them either here or on the google group

also, regarding the working of rm command, rm will only unlink the associated data from the file name in the filesystem, and it marks the associated space as usable on the device. We won't actually get rid of the data on the disk
so, to remove stuff like your browser history, use shred command instead. This will overwrite all of the data on the disk, and so it can't be reconstructed again also.
